abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Power Sector Development
            Operation Project for Uganda were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            high, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: electricity shortages need to
            be addressed from both supply side (generation) and demand
            side (energy efficiency) as they complement each other; as
            evidenced by the results of the project that resulted in
            contributions of about 1,000 GWh from the 50 MW Mutundwe
            plant on the supply side over the 4 years, and about 10 GWh
            from the demand side, out of savings arising from energy
            efficiency measures. In view of the planned new major
            investments, the Government has to implement measures to
            improve institutional and financial performance in advance
            of these investments. These measures include plans to
            facilitate a financially sustainable sector in the medium
            term highlighting the sector committed investments including
            the associated financing and implementation plans. The post
            project closing events, arising out of not having adequate
            budget provisions to ensure the continuing operations of
            thermal plants highlight the need for the stakeholders to
            continue high level dialog on key policy issues beyond the
            project period.
